title: Clear niche partitioning of nitrite-oxidizing bacteria from the bottom and the slope of Mariana Trench - Microbiome
description: Background The hadal zone, characterized by extreme hydrostatic pressure and geographic isolation, hosts microbial communities uniquely adapted to these harsh conditions. While niche partitioning has been observed in other deep-sea environments, its existence within hadal trench ecosystems remains controversial. Slope-dominant NOB harboured expanded genetic arsenals for antioxidation (e.g. superoxide dismutase) and osmoprotection (compatible solute transporters), Suggesting enhanced adaptive capacity to pressure-adjacent stresses. Abstract

Background

The hadal zone, characterized by extreme hydrostatic pressure and geographic isolation, hosts microbial communities uniquely adapted to these harsh conditions. While niche partitioning has been observed in other deep-sea environments, its existence within hadal trench ecosystems remains controversial. Focusing on the Mariana Trench, we investigated whether nitrite-oxidizing bacteria (NOB) exhibit depth-stratified ecological specialization between slope (6000–10,000 m) and bottom (> 10,000 m) sediments. By analysing the genomic features and ecological interactions of NOB, we aimed to resolve their functional roles in nitrogen cycling under distinct hadal microniches.

Results

We reconstructed 8 high-quality NOB metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) from 58 sediment metagenomes, revealing stark niche differentiation between depth zones. Slope-dominant NOB harboured expanded genetic arsenals for antioxidation (e.g. superoxide dismutase) and osmoprotection (compatible solute transporters), Suggesting enhanced adaptive capacity to pressure-adjacent stresses. Metatranscriptomics revealed 1.48 × (nxrA) and 1.28 × (aclA) greater expression of nitrite oxidation and carbon fixation genes in slope communities than in their bottom counterparts. Network analysis identified slope NOB as keystone taxa with elevated among-module connectivity and intramodule linkages, in contrast with bottom NOB, which exhibited localized nitrate-production gene networks. Functional profiling revealed complementary biogeochemical roles: slope NOB primarily consumed nitrite, whereas bottom populations dominated nitrate synthesis.

Conclusion

Our multiomics analysis revealed depth-dependent niche partitioning among hadal NOB, with transcriptional and network evidence supporting distinct pressure adaptation strategies and biogeochemical functions. The slope-bottom differentiation in stress response systems and nitrogen transformation pathways highlights how micron-scale environmental gradients drive microbial specialization in Earth’s deepest ecosystems. These findings establish NOB as critical mediators of hadal biogeochemical cycles and provide a framework for understanding microbial resilience in extreme biospheres.

Introduction

The Mariana Trench is the deepest part of the ocean, ranging from 6000 to 11,000 m in depth and accounting for approximately 45% of the ocean’s vertical depth gradient [1]. Characterized by extreme conditions such as high pressure, complete darkness, and low temperature, this environment shapes a unique microbial community that differs significantly from those found in other oceanic regions [2,3,4,5]. In terms of species diversity, Zhou et al. reported that 26± 7% of 16S rDNA fragments from the Challenger Deep sediment had not been previously identified in the SILVA database [6]. With respect to metabolic potential, Chen et al. reported that single-cell amplified genomes of deep-sea Roseobacter and Alteromonas contained more genes related to mobilomes and metal transport [7]. Similarly, Zhu et al. reported that Bacteroidetes from the hadal zone possessed more CAZyme-related genes than did their counterparts in surface waters [8]. In addition, the V-shaped topography of the trench facilitates the accumulation of materials from lateral transport and the ocean surface at the bottom, leading to ecological differences between the bottom and slope [9, 10]. For example, the proportion of novel 16S rDNA fragments increases with depth, and anammox activity has been observed only in surface sediments at the bottom [6]. The accumulation of heavy metals here also suggests microbial detoxification processes [11]. In summary, the microorganisms in hadal trench sediments exhibit unique adaptations to their extreme environments [12].

Nitrite-oxidizing bacteria (NOB) possess nitrite oxidase, enabling them to produce nitrate [13]. In addition to comammox bacteria, they are the only known microbial sources of nitrate [14]. NOB can be categorized into two types based on their key enzyme nitrite oxidoreductase: the cytoplasmic type and the periplasmic type. The cytoplasmic type, such as Nitrobacter and Nitrococcus, thrives in environments with high nitrite concentrations, whereas the periplasmic type, including Nitrospira and Nitrospina, is better suited to low nitrite concentrations [13]. All NOB groups are capable of carbon fixation through the Calvin‒Benson‒Bassham (CBB) cycle or the reverse tricarboxylic acid (rTCA) cycle [15,16,17]. Some NOB can also oxidize simple organic compounds, such as formate, in mixotrophic mode or oxidize hydrogen and sulphur compounds for energy [18, 19]. In previous studies on the Mariana Trench, NOB such as Nitrospira and Nitrospirae, but not comammox, were identified [5, 6]. Recent studies have demonstrated that nitrate serves as an essential electron acceptor in hadal trenches and may be even more important than oxygen. For example, the high hydrostatic pressure in the trench stimulates the generation of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS), leading microbes to use alternative electron acceptors, such as nitrate from microbial nitrification [20], even in the presence of oxygen [20,21,22,23]. Therefore, as the sole producers of nitrate, NOB are expected to play a critical role in nitrogen and carbon cycling in the hadal environment.

Previous studies have shown that microbes can evolve distinct metabolic traits and exhibit varying metabolic potential to adapt to different microenvironments—even those with relatively low abundance [24,25,26,27]. Accordingly, NOB at the bottom and along the slope of hadal trenches may perform different ecological functions. On the one hand, the high hydrostatic pressure at the trench bottom can create oxygen stress and demand more energy, potentially hindering NOB activity [22, 28, 29]. On the other hand, the lower carbon-to-nitrogen ratio at the bottom (compared with the slope) can stimulate NOB growth [30,31,32]. As organisms serve as the sole biological source of nitrate, NOB are critical for adjusting the redox gradient and carbon–nitrogen coupling in these deep-ocean environments. Determining whether NOB exhibit clear partitioning in the hadal zone is therefore vital to refining our understanding of community assemblages and elemental cycling in these extreme environments.

In this study, by leveraging metagenomic and metatranscriptomic approaches, we reconstructed high-quality NOB MAGs, examined their metabolic pathways and environmental adaptations, and explored their ecological interactions within microbial communities. Furthermore, we investigated the niche separation of NOB between slope and bottom sediments, revealing significant differences in their community composition and transcriptional activity. Our findings not only expand the current knowledge of NOB diversity and function in hadal environments but also shed light on the ecological processes driving nitrogen cycling in the deepest parts of the ocean.

Methods

Sampling sites and published datasets

For the 35 samples included in this study (labelled “this study” in Supplementary Table S1), sediment push core samples were collected from the Mariana Trench during cruises TS21 in 2021 and DY37-II in 2016. The surface sediments (0 ~ 10 cmbsf) were immersed in RNAlater in situ and stored at − 80 °C on board until sequencing. The RNAlater was prepared according to the recipe (dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.c56y9d). In addition, 23 metagenomic datasets from previous studies were collected [33,34,35,36]. The sampling sites were visualized via GMT [37]. The publications, accession numbers, and information of these datasets are shown in Supplementary Table S1. The methods of extraction and sequencing for DNA and RNA are described in the supplementary methods.

Metagenomics and metatranscriptomics

First, the raw reads were trimmed by fastp (version 0.23.4) with the parameters “-q 20 -u 20 -g -c -W 5–3 -l 90” [38]. Then, the assembly was performed by using MEGAHIT (version 1.2.9) [39] with “–presets meta-sensitive” for each sample. Contigs shorter than 1000 bp were discarded. Reads mapping and binning were performed with MetaWRAP (version 1.3) [40]. First, read mapping was performed via BWA with the default parameters in MetaWRAP. Three primary MAG sets were subsequently obtained with MetaBAT2, MaxBin2, and CONCOCT. Finally, the refinement module of MetaWRAP was used to integrate the primary MAG sets.

Quality and taxonomy were determined by using CheckM (version 1.2.2) and GTDB-Tk tools (version 2.4.1) with the GTDB database (version 226), respectively [41,42,43]. Specifically, the quality of MAGs classified as Patescibacteria was based on the marker gene set [44]. Only MAGs with completeness > 70% and contamination < 5% were retained for downstream analysis, meeting or exceeding the criteria for medium-quality MAGs [45]. The remaining MAGs were dereplicated with dRep (version 3.2.2) with a threshold of 95% by ANImf methods [46]. Skani was performed with the default parameter to calculate the average nucleotide identity (ANI) value for each pair of MAGs [47], and fastAAI was performed with the default parameter to calculate the average amino acid identity (AAI) value among the MAGs in this study and reference genomes [48]. The distribution was estimated via read recruitment. Recruitments were performed via BBmap with the parameter “k = 15 minid = 0.95 minaveragequality = 5”. Qualified hits were used to compute the RPKM values via coverM (https://github.com/wwood/CoverM), which reflects a normalized abundance allowing comparisons across different genomes and metagenomes.

For the metagenomic assembly and reference MAGs retrieved from the GTDB database, gene prediction was performed via Prodigal (version 2.6.3), and ORFs with lengths smaller than 33 amino acids were trimmed [49]. Gene annotation was primarily performed by using KofamKOALA (version 1.3.0) against the KEGG database (version 20231230) and DIAMOND (version 2.0.14) against the UniProtKB database (version 20240124) and emapper (version 2.1.7) against the EggNOB database (version 5.0.2) [50,51,52,53,54], with identity > 30% and coverage of the query > 30%. The alignment should be longer than 50% of the query sequence and 50% of the subject sequences. Potential carbohydrate-active enzymes were identified via dbcan [55]. Finally, featureCounts (version 2.0.1) was used to count the read number of each gene based on the bam file during binning, and the TPM value was calculated with a custom Python script [56]. All the above processes were performed for both the samples collected in this study and previously reported samples.

For the metatranscriptomic datasets, raw reads were first trimmed by fastp to filter poor-quality bases and then filtered by RiboDetector to remove rRNA reads [57, 58]. The unaligned mRNA reads were mapped to the representative MAGs via BBmap. Then, featureCounts was used to count the read number of each gene [56]. Finally, a custom Python script was used to calculate the TPM value.

Statistical analyses and visualizations

All the statistical analyses and visualizations were performed via R (http://www.rproject.org/). The significance of differences (Wilcoxon test and t-test) for the RPKM and TPM values was analysed via the ggpubr package (https://rpkgs.datanovia.com/ggpubr/). For the Wilcoxon test in Figs. 2c and 3, the resulting p-values were adjusted for multiple comparisons via the Benjamini–Hochberg false discovery rate (FDR). The nonmetric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) and adonis2 analyses were performed via the vegan package (https://github.com/vegandevs/vegan/). Visualization was performed via the ggplot2 package (https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2).

Phylogenetic tree

For the tree of MAGs in Fig. 1C, the bacterial single-copy gene sets were identified via the GTDB-Tk tool. Then, for each marker gene set, aligning and trimming with the same parameter were performed separately by using MAFFT (version 7.490) and trimAL (version 1.4) with the automated1 model [59, 60]. All the alignments were subsequently concatenated for each genome. IQTREE (version 2.2.0.3) was used to construct the phylogenetic tree with the TEST model [61]. The tree was visualized via iTOL v6 [62]. For the tree of MAGs in Supplementary Fig. S1, 40 single-copy gene sets were identified via fetchMG (version 1.2), and the subsequent procedure was the same as above (https://github.com/motu-tool/FetchMGs). For the tree of nxrA (nitrite oxidoreductase, alpha subunit) and nxrB (nitrite oxidoreductase, beta subunit) genes in Fig. 1B and Supplementary Fig. S3, reference genes were from (1) outgroups from UniProt databases, (2) predicted genes from reference MAGs of reported NOB in the GTDB database, and (3) the KEGG and Ncyc databases. The methods for prediction and annotation were the same as those in the manuscript. The selected reference genes were clustered by cd-hit with “-c 0.7 -aS 0.7” for rapid construction of the phylogenetic tree. The subsequent procedure was the same as that described above. The details of the sequence number, remaining columns, and selected model of each tree are given in Supplementary Table S3.

Co-occurrence network

Spearman’s rank correlation analysis was employed to construct the co-occurrence networks with the R package “igraph”, and Gephi software (version 0.10.1) was employed to visualize the co-occurrence networks and analyse the modularity class. The ecological role of each MAG was determined via previous methods [63]. Specifically, nodes with a within‐module degree (Zi) greater than 2.5 and among‐module connectivity (Pi) less than 0.62 were classified as module hubs, whereas nodes with a Zi less than 2.5 and Pi less than 0.62 were classified as peripherals. The metabolic profiles of the MAGs were determined by the presence of functional genes. MAGs containing amoABC genes were classified as ammonia oxidizers; those with genes related to carbon fixation were classified as other autotrophs (Supplementary Table S4); MAGs harbouring narGH or napAB were classified as nitrate reducers, and all other MAGs were classified as other putative heterotrophs.

Results

Reconstruction of NOB MAGs in Mariana Trench sediment

We analysed 58 metagenomic datasets obtained from Surface sediments at 18 sampling sites in the Mariana Trench (Fig. 1a, Supplementary Table S1). Based on the water depth, the datasets were categorized into two groups: “bottom” (depth > 10 km) and “slope” (depth 6 ~ 10 km). Through binning, we reconstructed 1889 metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) of high quality (completeness > 70% and contamination < 5%) (Supplementary Table S2). After dereplication at a 95% ANI threshold, 399 representative MAGs were retained. The mapping rates for quality-controlled reads ranged from 12.72% to 33.64%, with an average of 25.00%. Taxonomic classification via GTDB-Tk revealed that these 399 MAGs encompassed 3 archaeal and 35 bacterial phyla (Supplementary Fig. S1).

To identify MAGs with the potential to oxidize nitrite, we constructed phylogenetic trees to examine the presence of the key genes nxrA and nxrB. For nxrA, three distinct clades were observed, corresponding to the Nitrospinales-like, Nitrospirales-like, and anammox-associated nxrA genes (Fig. 1b). Sequences from metagenomic assemblies were also included in the phylogenetic analysis. The results indicated that 13 out of the 17 NOB-associated nxrA genes were successfully binned into our MAGs. Sequence alignments revealed key features, including a twin-arginine translocation (Tat) signal peptide at the N-terminus, iron‒sulphur (Fe‒S) cluster residues, and molybdenum-coordinating residues [16, 64, 65] (Supplementary Fig. S2). Similarly, three clades were identified for nxrB, corresponding to those observed for nxrA (Supplementary Fig. S3). Seven of the 11 nxrB genes from the metagenomic assembly were also successfully binned into our MAGs. Although only group MT45 lacked nxrB genes, MAG MT45-1 possessed nxrA genes. As the MAGs in this group were classified as Nitrospinales, a common NOB lineage, they were thus designated NOB MAGs. Notably, no narG or narH genes were identified in any NOB MAGs.

As a result, eight representative MAGs containing both NOB-associated nxrA and nxrB genes were identified, excluding the MT50, which contains only the NOB-associated nxrB gene (Fig. 1c, Table 1). These MAGs included a wide range of genome sizes (1.89 ~ 3.53 Mbp) and GC contents (47.73% ~ 59.27%), reflecting substantial genomic diversity. Notably, MAGs MT49-1 and MT45-1 lacked closely related reference genomes in the GTDB database, with AAI values below the established thresholds for family (81.34 ± 8.32%) and species (94.98 ± 0.37%) levels, respectively [48] (Supplementary Table S2).

Diversity and niche partitioning of different NOB MAGs

Mapping of the metagenomic reads against all the representative MAGs revealed that NOB accounted for 0.58% ~ 4.91% of the prokaryotic community (Supplementary Fig. S4). MAGs belonging to Nitrospinales were more abundant than those from Nitrospirales, and the RPKM values indicated that NOB were more prevalent in slope samples than in bottom samples. The findings also suggested a potential niche preference for the identified NOB, as MAGs from the same cluster were often derived from datasets of the same type, except cluster MT306. For example, MAGs in cluster MT47 were reconstructed exclusively from metagenomic datasets from slope sediments. To validate these observations, Wilcoxon tests were performed on the RPKM values of representative MAGs within each cluster. The results revealed that clusters MT306, MT307, MT308, and MT47 were significantly more abundant at the slope, whereas the other clusters were significantly more abundant at the bottom (Wilcoxon test, p < 0.01) (Fig. 2a). Additionally, NMDS analysis revealed significant differences in NOB composition between the slope and bottom samples (Fig. 2b; Adonis analysis, p < 0.01).

We analysed metatranscriptomic datasets to assess the expression profiles of key functional genes in NOB MAGs across slope and bottom environments (Fig. 2c and d). Given the pivotal roles of NOB in nitrite oxidation and carbon fixation, we focused on the genes nxrA (for nitrite oxidoreductase), cydA (for cytochrome bd ubiquinol oxidase), ccoO (for cytochrome c oxidase cbb3 type), and aclA (for ATP-citrate lyase of the rTCA cycle).

Although the overall differences in gene expression between the two environments were not statistically significant, the nxrA gene presented slightly greater transcriptional activity in the slope samples (Fig. 2c, Wilcoxon test, not significant). Notably, the NOB groups MT50, MT47, and MT306 were among the most transcriptionally active (Fig. 2d). Specifically, nxrA genes from MT47 and MT306 presented elevated transcriptional activity in slope samples (Fig. 3, Wilcoxon test, not significant). While MT50 was more abundant in the bottom samples (Fig. 2a), its nxrA gene maintained high transcriptional activity in both environments.

With respect to carbon fixation, the aclA genes in NOB MAGs presented similar transcription levels across both environments (Fig. 2c). The primary contributors to aclA transcription were MT47, MT45, and MT48 (Fig. 2d). MT47 presented significantly greater transcriptional activity on the slope (Wilcoxon test, FDR < 0.05), whereas MT45 and MT48 presented greater activity at the bottom (Wilcoxon test, not significant) (Fig. 3).

Additionally, the cytochrome oxidase genes cydA and ccoO demonstrated varying transcriptional activities between the slope and bottom environments (Fig. 2c), although the main contributing NOB groups remained similar (Fig. 2d). Overall, at the bottom, MT45, MT48, MT50, and MT306 were the primary contributors to both carbon fixation and nitrite oxidation, whereas at the slope MT50, MT47, and MT306 were the predominant contributors.

Metabolic potential and transcriptional activity of NOB MAGs across different niches

To investigate how these NOB MAGs exhibit niche partitioning, we analysed the presence and transcriptional activity of key genes in each MAG (Fig. 4a). For nitrogen metabolism, no amoABC genes were identified in the 8 representative MAGs or the 71 redundant MAGs, confirming that all detected MAGs are canonical NOB. In addition to the nitrite-oxidizing nxrAB genes, all eight NOB groups possess the NRT2 gene, which is responsible for nitrate/nitrite transport. In addition to genes involved in nitrite oxidation, genes involved in nitrite reduction were also identified. Metagenomic analysis revealed that all eight NOB MAGs encode nirK (nitrite reductase to nitric oxide, NO), whereas six MAGs possess nirBD (nitrite reductase to ammonia). Additionally, genes for ammonia assimilation (glnA, gltBD) and the nitrogen-responsive two-component regulatory system glnLG were detected in all NOB MAGs. Notably, NOB taxa abundant on slopes harboured norBC, encoding nitric oxide reductase (NO to nitrous oxide). Collectively, these findings indicate diverse nitrite utilization pathways within the studied NOB MAGs. Metatranscriptomic data further demonstrated greater transcriptional activity for nirK genes (which are active in all eight MAGs) than for nirBD genes (which are active in only one of the six MAGs).

For carbon metabolism, all NOB MAGs possess a nearly complete rTCA cycle, including the key genes aclAB and porABDC, indicating their potential for carbon fixation (Fig. 4a). Additionally, six MAGs contained ccAB genes, although no ccl genes were detected. However, the acnAB genes were entirely absent, and korABDC was only partially present in some MAGs. A similar pattern was observed in the TCA cycle, with acnAB and OGDH missing across all MAGs. Distinct metabolic pathways were identified among specific NOB groups. Nitrospinales MAGs encode genes for formate degradation (fdhAB), indicating alternative energy supplementation. In contrast, Nitrospirales MAGs uniquely possess the SUOX gene, encoding sulphite oxidase, which may enable energy generation. Additionally, the MAG MT-50 (Nitrospinales) harbours active genes for urea degradation and transport, potentially providing additional formate and energy (Fig. 4b). Furthermore, most Nitrospinales MAGs demonstrate the capacity for partial sulphate reduction to sulphite via an incomplete assimilatory sulphate reduction pathway (Fig. 4).

Moreover, all identified NOB groups possess two types of complex IV (cydAB and ccoNOPQ), indicative of their microaerobic lifestyle [66, 67] (Fig. 2). For antioxidation, the trxB gene was found in all MAGs. Similarly, the AS3MT and GSTO1 genes, which convert environmental arsenic into cacodylate, are universally present. The MAGs that were more abundant in the slope samples also included additional antioxidation-related genes. For example, MAGs MT306 and MT307 possess the gpx gene, and MAGs MT307 and MT308 have the cpo gene, both of which are involved in the reduction of H2O2 (Fig. 4). These differences extend to mechanisms for coping with high hydrostatic pressure. Slope-abundant MAGs carry genes encoding transporters for spermidine (potABCD), glycine betaine (proXWY), and trehalose (thuEFGK), which are compatible with solutes that mitigate pressure stress (Fig. 4). The metatranscriptomic results indicate that all of the aforementioned genes are actively transcribed (Fig. 4b).

Distinct ecological roles of NOB across niches revealed by co-occurrence networks

The microbial co-occurrence network analysis revealed a complex and highly interconnected community structure (Fig. 5a). The network consisted of 367 nodes, representing distinct microbial taxa, and 19,996 edges, which indicate significant co-occurrence relationships based on Spearman’s correlation (ρ > 0.6, p < 0.01). The network exhibited a modular structure, with five distinct modules identified. Among these microbial taxa, specific groups of NOBs were distributed across the network in distinct patterns. Four NOB groups—MT45, MT48, MT49, and MT50—were found to cluster together within module 1. These taxa presented relatively high relative abundances in the bottom sediment samples, Suggesting that module 1 is associated primarily with bottom-dwelling microbial communities. In contrast, four other NOB MAGs were identified in slope sediment samples and were clustered together within module 3, which consisted of slope-abundant MAGs.

The degree centrality of the taxa revealed notable differences between the bottom-abundant and slope-abundant groups. The four NOB taxa in module 1 presented greater degrees (53 ~ 111) than the other NOB groups did (1 ~ 25), indicating a greater number of connections with other taxa within the network. However, when network centrality metrics were evaluated, the slope-abundant groups were found to be more central within the overall network, reflecting their involvement in broader intermodule connectivity. Based on ecological roles within the network, MT47, MT307, and MT308 were identified as module hubs. The remaining five MAGs, including the bottom-abundant NOB taxa in module 1, were classified as peripherals (Fig. 5b) [63].

Upon recognizing the distinct ecological roles of NOB in the slope and bottom environments, we further analysed their functional differences. First, we classified other MAGs based on the presence or absence of functional genes, characterizing their metabolic profiles (see Methods and Supplementary Table S4). In module 1, NOB were Linked with 128 MAGs, including 2 ammonia-oxidizing archaea (AOA), 30 Nitrate-reducing bacteria, and 96 potential Heterotrophic microbes from other clades. In module 3, NOB were associated with 55 nodes, including 9 ammonia-oxidizing microbes (8 AOA and 1 ammonia-oxidizing bacteria (AOB)), 4 Nitrate-reducing bacteria, and 42 potential heterotrophic microbes from other clades. Second, based on the relative abundance of these MAGs, we analysed the types of microorganisms with which NOB interact. The proportion of heterotrophic microbes Linked to NOB in module 1 was significantly greater (60.06% ± 6.22%) than that in module 3 (38.90% ± 17.33%) (t-test, p < 0.05). A similar trend was observed for nitrate-reducing bacteria (bottom: 14.23% ± 4.84%, slope: 1.38% ± 1.01%, t-test, p < 0.05). The proportion of ammonia-oxidizing microbes in module 3 was notably greater than that in module 1 (bottom: 23.44% ± 6.40%, slope: 59.72% ± 17.81%, t-test, p < 0.05) (Supplementary Fig. S5a). Additionally, the two modules presented distinct species compositions. In module 3, the ammonia-oxidizing groups included both AOA and AOB, whereas those in module 1 contained only AOA. Although both modules contained Heterotrophic microbes from the groups Pseudomonadota, Chloroflexota, and Gemmatimonadota, module 1 was predominantly composed of Planctomycetota and Marinisomatota, whereas module 3 was dominated by Acidobacteriota and Desulfobacterota_B (Supplementary Fig. S5b). Overall, NOB in the bottom environment were associated with a greater number of nitrate reducers and putative heterotrophs, whereas NOB in the slope environment were more strongly associated with ammonia oxidizers. Based on these findings, we hypothesize that NOB play distinct roles in the bottom and slope regions of the hadal trench, supporting different microbial communities. In the bottom region, NOB supplies organic matter and nitrate to heterotrophic communities, whereas in the slope region, NOB primarily consumes nitrite produced by AOA and provides organic matter to heterotrophic microbes (Fig. 5c).

Discussion

The bottom and slope zones harbour a distinct community of nitrite-oxidizing bacteria

We obtained a total of eight representative NOB MAGs from the metagenomic datasets of sediment samples from the Mariana Trench (Fig. 1). These NOB MAGs clearly show niche participation from slope to bottom in terms of taxonomy and gene expression (Figs. 2 and 3). Most of the NOB detected belonged to the class Nitrospinia, which is consistent with the dominance of Nitrospinales in previous reports from global oceans [68]. With no amoABC genes found in these NOB MAGs, sediments of the Mariana Trench are unlikely to support comammox microorganisms (Fig. 4A). Based on the classification of the GTDB-Tk tools, MT45 and MT49 have no reference genomes in the GTDB r220 database, suggesting that they may belong to a putative novel family (MT45) and novel species (MT49). Zhou et al. reported that microbiome novelty is positively correlated with water depth in the Mariana Trench, which is consistent with the finding that novel NOB were found only in the bottom samples [6].

The transcriptional activity of key genes further supports the hypothesis of functional differentiation between the slope and bottom NOB communities. The slightly higher expression of the nxrA gene in slope samples suggests enhanced nitrite oxidation activity under these conditions, likely driven by greater substrate availability (such as nitrite), higher nitrate demands, or the need for rapid nitrite consumption [69, 70]. Similarly, the higher expression of the aclA gene in slope samples than in bottom samples indicates that NOB in slopes may provide more organic matter to heterotrophic microbes [71, 72]. These results align with those of previous trench sediment studies. Glud et al. quantified benthic oxygen consumption, sedimentary 210Pb distribution, organic carbon content, photopigment concentrations, and microbial biomass in the Mariana Trench and reported increased microbial respiration rates and elevated prokaryotic densities within the deepest sediment horizons [9]. Similarly, Nunoura et al. integrated geochemical profiling with 16S rRNA gene sequencing across water‒sediment interfaces, revealing accelerated particulate organic carbon deposition rates and distinct biogeochemical stratification in hadal deposits [73]. These observations substantiate a mechanistic framework wherein recurring submarine mass transport events deliver labile organic substrates to hadal zones. This supply of allochthonous carbon effectively supplies the need for heterotrophic microbiota to rely on carbon fixation mediated by NOB. These findings collectively highlight the complex interplay between environmental factors and the metabolic versatility of NOB. However, further discussion is needed to fully elucidate the reasons behind niche partitioning and its ecological implications.

Differences in high hydrostatic pressure adaptation capabilities drive niche partitioning

Microorganisms in trenches are typically exposed to extremely high hydrostatic pressures, which affect both their cellular structures and metabolic activities [28]. To assess the capacity of NOB to adapt to high hydrostatic pressure in trench environments—and to determine whether such adaptations underpin ecological niche partitioning—we analysed the distribution and transcriptional activity of genes associated with energy generation, antioxidant defence, and compatible‐solute transport in the MAGs. These genes have previously been reported to confer adaptation to high hydrostatic pressure [29, 74,75,76,77].

In general, NOB identified in the Mariana Trench appears to have a strong capacity to generate energy and cope with high hydrostatic pressure and oxidative stress. For most of the NOB groups in this study, additional energy supplementation pathways were observed in addition to nitrite oxidation and the TCA cycle: formate degradation for Nitrospinales and sulphite oxidation for Nitrospirales (Fig. 4). These additional energy sources help NOB better adapt to the extreme conditions of the hadal trench, such as high hydrostatic pressure [28]. The potential for antioxidation was also observed. For example, the trxB gene was present in all MAGs. The product, thioredoxin disulphide, facilitates the reduction of disulfide bonds in target proteins, thereby restoring their functional conformations and protecting cells from oxidative stress by directly or indirectly reducing ROS and other oxidized molecules [78]. They also have the genes AS3MT and GSTO1, which convert toxic trivalent arsenic ions in the environment into the less toxic organic arsenic compound DMA(V), a compound with lower toxicity [79, 80] (Fig. 4). Owing to the V-shaped structure of hadal trenches, heavy metal ions tend to accumulate in these areas [1]. Heavy metal ions also pose oxidative stress to microorganisms by binding to their iron‒sulphur clusters [81]. The released Fe2+ can participate in the Fenton reaction to generate hydroxyl radicals, highly increasing ROS levels. Converting inorganic arsenic into organic arsenic can prevent its interference with microorganisms, thereby maintaining their antioxidant capacity [82].

Slope-abundant NOB, which exhibit elevated transcriptional activity for nitrite oxidation (Fig. 2C), contain additional genes related to antioxidation. This adaptation likely counters the oxidative stress associated with their metabolism. The rTCA cycle relies on iron‒sulphur proteins for electron transfer, which are highly susceptible to irreversible oxidation in the presence of oxygen, rendering the cycle nonfunctional [83]. However, active nitrite oxidation requires oxygen, increasing the level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) [84]. Similarly, slope-abundant NOB prefers cytochrome bd oxidase (cydA) instead of cytochrome cbb3 oxidase (ccoO) (Fig. 2), as cydA has increased oxygen affinity and contributes to ROS detoxification, thereby maintaining the cellular redox balance [85,86,87].

Moreover, slope-abundant NOB contain genes encoding nitric oxide reductase, indicating their ability to effectively regulate the concentration of NO, which is critical for both NO recruitment and NO regulation but potentially toxic when excessive [88]. For example, when regulating electron flow, NO binds to cytochrome oxidase, and its overabundance can impair NOB’s ability to utilize oxygen [89]. Moreover, as a reactive nitrogen species, NO can react with other reactive molecules to form stronger oxidants, leading to cellular damage and oxidative stress [90]. Efficiently reducing NO helps alleviate these oxidative stresses and ensures cellular resilience [91].

Interestingly, despite the lower hydrostatic pressure at the slope than at the bottom, slope-abundant NOB exhibit enhanced adaptation mechanisms for pressure conditions, with several genes linked to osmoregulation. These genes encode transporters for compatible solutes such as spermidine, glycine betaine, and trehalose. Therefore, these NOB can allocate more energy to cope with the ROS generated during the active nitrite oxidation process. Therefore, we propose that niche partitioning is due to differences in pressure adaptation and antioxidant capabilities.

NOB play distinct roles in carbon and nitrogen cycling at the slope and bottom of the Mariana Trench

Through co-occurrence network analysis, we found that the NOB in the slope and bottom regions support different microbial communities, suggesting that they may play distinct ecological roles (Fig. 5a, b and Supplementary Fig. S5). Compared with bottom sediments, slope sediments have lower organic matter contents and higher oxygen concentrations [10, 31, 92]. Consequently, microbial communities in slope sediments depend less on nitrate due to reduced organic matter degradation activities and increased oxygen availability. Although slope-abundant NOB exhibit relatively high nitrite oxidation activity, their primary ecological function appears to be the removal of nitrite to alleviate toxicity to other microbes [93]. Additionally, the organic matter produced through carbon fixation supports some heterotrophic microorganisms, compensating for the lower organic matter availability in the slope.

In contrast, the bottom sediments, with their relatively high organic matter content and low oxygen conditions, necessitate that heterotrophic communities depend heavily on additional oxidative power, driving a greater reliance on nitrate utilization [9]. Furthermore, increased hydrostatic pressure promotes microbial nitrate utilization. These factors increase the microbial dependence on nitrate at the bottom, strengthening the interactions between NOB, the sole nitrate producers, and nitrate-reducing bacteria. Moreover, because the organic matter at the bottom is relatively inert, many heterotrophic microorganisms capable of complex organic matter degradation also interact with NOB [10, 31]. Overall, NOB play distinct roles in the community assemblages of the slope and bottom regions (Fig. 5c).

In conclusion, this study highlights the ecological and functional diversity of NOB in Mariana Trench sediments, revealing their adaptive strategies and niche differentiation between slope and bottom environments. Differences in gene content and transcriptional profiles suggest distinct metabolic capacities and adaptations, including pressure adaptation and antioxidant capabilities. The co-occurrence network revealed that NOB play different roles in supporting community assembly and mediating carbon and nitrogen cycling at the slope and bottom of the Mariana Trench. We recognize that the absence of in situ measurements, experimental validation, and biological replicates weakens these conclusions. Nevertheless, our findings underscore the environmental factors shaping NOB dynamics and their broader role in deep-ocean biogeochemical cycles.
